summary.text_en: On March 25, 1655, using a powerful telescope he and his brother Constantijn had built, Christiaan Huygens observed a bright object near Saturn. After tracking it for several nights, he confirmed it was orbiting the planet. This was the first new moon discovered in the solar system since Galileo's discovery of Jupiter's moons nearly 50 years earlier (`galileo_telescope_1610`). He named it 'Saturni Luna' (Saturn's Moon), which we now call Titan.
key_points_en: First new moon discovered after the Galilean moons
Provided the first clue to the complexity of the Saturnian system

story.text_en: The Huygens brothers (Christiaan and Constantijn) were the world's leading lens-grinders in the mid-17th century. They developed new techniques to create telescopes with longer focal lengths, higher magnification, and less chromatic aberration ('color fringing'). When Galileo (`galileo_telescope_1610`) looked at Saturn, he was baffled by its strange shape, which he called 'ears'. But Huygens, using his superior 50-power telescope in 1655, was able to not only resolve the tiny dot orbiting the planet (Titan), but would also, a few years later (1659), be the one to finally solve the mystery of its 'ears': a 'thin, flat Ring' (`huygens_saturn_rings_1659`).

fun_facts.text_en: To protect his priority while he confirmed the observation (from rivals like Hooke and Cassini), Huygens first published his discovery as a Latin anagram in 1656.
In 2005, the European Space Agency's 'Huygens' probe successfully landed on Titan after a 7-year, 3.5-billion-km journey, honoring his discovery.

simple_explanation.text_en: Galileo used his telescope to find Jupiter's 4 big moons. Half a century later, Huygens built a much better 'high-definition' telescope. When he pointed it at Saturn (which Galileo just saw as a weird 'triple-planet'), he spotted a tiny, faint 'sidekick' next to it. By watching for a few nights, he proved this 'sidekick' was orbiting Saturn. He had discovered Titan, proving the solar system was even more complex than thought and that *better instruments* were the key to discovery.

applications.text_en: Titan's orbital period (~16 days) provided another crucial 'data point' for Kepler's Laws and, later, for Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation (`newton_gravity_1687`).

applications.text_en: The discovery was a triumph of 'instrument-driven science', proving that improving lens-grinding technology (optics) directly led to major astronomical breakthroughs.

impact.text_en: Huygens's discovery of Titan was the 'second wave' of the Copernican Revolution. Galileo had shown Jupiter was a 'mini solar system', and Huygens now proved Saturn was one too. This further shattered the Aristotelian-Ptolemaic model that *everything* must orbit the Earth. It showed that complex satellite systems for planets might be the *norm*, not the exception.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Galileo (whose discovery of Jupiter's moons and baffling observations of Saturn was Huygens's starting point)
Kepler (whose laws provided the framework for Huygens to calculate Titan's orbit)

influenced.contribution_en: (Himself) This discovery spurred him to keep observing Saturn, leading to his solving of the Ring mystery in 1659
Giovanni Cassini (who was inspired to look for *more* moons around Saturn, finding the next four)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Huygens, by building a better 'eye' (the telescope), revealed a brand new world to the human race.

quiz.question_en: How did Huygens discover Titan in 1655, whereas Galileo had failed to?
options_en: He used a much more powerful, self-made telescope
He received ancient star charts from China
He applied Newton's law of gravitation
quiz.explanation_en: Huygens was a master 'optician' and lens-grinder. His telescope (at ~50x) was far more powerful and clearer than Galileo's (~20x), allowing him to resolve the faint moon of Titan, which had been invisible to Galileo.
